{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1348\cocoasubrtf170 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaBright;\f1\fnil\fcharset0 DejaVuSansMono;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red25\green25\blue25;} \pard\tx720\tx1440\tx2160\tx2880\tx3600\tx4320\tx5040\tx5760\tx6480\tx7200\tx7920\tx8640\tx9360\tx10080\tx10800\tx11520\tx12240\tx12960\tx13680\tx14400\tx15120\tx15840\tx16560\tx17280\sb320
\f0\fs64 \cf2 In terms of existing ontologies, SWO, the \i Software Ontology \i0 ( \f1\fs62 http://theswo.sourceforge.net \f0\fs64 ), is the closest to our needs. It provides terms for topics, data formats, software licenses, and more. We are working with the SWO developers to extend it.\ With colleagues at NIST, we are also exploring the use of the NIST \i Dictionary of Algorithms and Data Structures \i0 ( \f1\fs62 https://xlinux.nist.gov/dads/ \f0\fs64 ).}

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1348\cocoasubrtf170 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaBright;\f1\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaGrande;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red25\green25\blue25;\red25\green25\blue25;} {\*\listtable{\list\listtemplateid1\listhybrid{\listlevel\levelnfc23\levelnfcn23\leveljc0\leveljcn0\levelfollow0\levelstartat1\levelspace360\levelindent0{\*\levelmarker \{square\}}{\leveltext\leveltemplateid1\'01\uc0\u9642 ;}{\levelnumbers;}\fi-360\li720\lin720 }{\listname ;}\listid1}} {\*\listoverridetable{\listoverride\listid1\listoverridecount0\ls1}} \pard\tx220\tx720\tx1120\tx1680\tx2240\tx2800\tx3360\tx3920\tx4480\tx5040\tx5600\tx6160\tx6720\li720\fi-720\sb40\pardirnatural \ls1\ilvl0 \f0\fs56 \cf2 \kerning1\expnd-2\expndtw-10 {\listtext \f1 \cf2 \kerning1\expnd-2\expndtw-10 \uc0\u9642 \f0 \cf2 \kerning1\expnd-2\expndtw-10 }Linares-V\'e1squez, et al. (2014). On using machine learning to automatically classify software applications into domain categories. \i Empirical Software Engineering \i0 , 19(3).\ \ls1\ilvl0\cf3 {\listtext \f1 \uc0\u9642 \f0 }Linstead, et al. (2008). Mining internet-scale software repositories. \i Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems \i0 , 20.\ {\listtext \f1 \uc0\u9642 \f0 }McMillan, et al. (2012). Exemplar: \kerning1\expnd-6\expndtw-30 A source code search engine for finding highly relevant application\kerning1\expnd-2\expndtw-10 s. \i IEEE Trans Soft. Eng. \i0 , 38(5).\ \pard\tx220\tx720\tx1120\tx1680\tx2240\tx2800\tx3360\tx3920\tx4480\tx5040\tx5600\tx6160\tx6720\li720\fi-720\sb40\pardirnatural \cf2 \kerning1\expnd-2\expndtw-10
\f1 \uc0\u9642 \f0 Ugurel, et al. (2002). What's the code? Automatic classification of source code archives. In \i KDD '02 \i0 .}

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1348\cocoasubrtf170 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaBright;\f1\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaBright-Demi;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red25\green25\blue25;} \pard\tx560\tx1120\tx1680\tx2240\tx2800\tx3360\tx3920\tx4480\tx5040\tx5600\tx6160\tx6720\sb360\pardirnatural
\f0\fs64 \cf2 We seek to \i automate a continually-updated index \i0 \i of \i0 \i software \i0 for users, particularly scientists. This will \kerning1\expnd-1\expndtw-5 require overcoming two challenges: \i effective softwar\kerning1\expnd0\expndtw0 e discovery \i0 and \i accurate software characterization \i0 . \ Our research question is: \f1\b can an ontology-based approach to software characterization produce results that humans find acceptable \f0\b0 ?}

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1348\cocoasubrtf170 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaBright;\f1\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaBright-Demi;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red25\green25\blue25;} \pard\tx560\tx1120\tx1680\tx2240\tx2800\tx3360\tx3920\tx4480\tx5040\tx5600\tx6160\tx6720\sb320\pardirnatural
\f0\fs64 \cf2 A \f1\b comprehensive software index \f0\b0 could make it easier to find software by providing pertinent results organized with contextual information and specific details about each software resource. This would help users find software more effectively and compare alternatives more systematically.\ Past cataloguing efforts have failed either because they were simplistic (thus providing incomplete, misleading or unhelpful content) or relied on humans. Humans don\'92t scale\'97 \f1\b automation is the only feasible way \f0\b0 of cataloging the vast and ever-growing number of constantly-evolving software applications, libraries and other sources.\ Happily, the growing trend of putting software in repositories such as GitHub opens new avenues.}

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1348\cocoasubrtf170 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaBright;\f1\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaGrande;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red25\green25\blue25;} {\*\listtable{\list\listtemplateid1\listhybrid{\listlevel\levelnfc23\levelnfcn23\leveljc0\leveljcn0\levelfollow0\levelstartat1\levelspace360\levelindent0{\*\levelmarker \{square\}}{\leveltext\leveltemplateid1\'01\uc0\u9642 ;}{\levelnumbers;}\fi-360\li720\lin720 }{\listname ;}\listid1}} {\*\listoverridetable{\listoverride\listid1\listoverridecount0\ls1}} \pard\tx220\tx720\tx1120\tx1680\tx2240\tx2800\tx3360\tx3920\tx4480\tx5040\tx5600\tx6160\tx6720\li720\fi-720\sb180\pardirnatural \ls1\ilvl0 \f0\i\fs64 \cf2 \expnd0\expndtw0\kerning0 {\listtext \f1\i0 \uc0\u9642 \f0\i }Must pick good terms \i0 . Difficult to do, worse for nonnative English speakers or field outsiders.\ \ls1\ilvl0 \i {\listtext \f1\i0 \uc0\u9642 \f0\i }Too many results \i0 . The relevant software can be buried and difficult to find.\ \ls1\ilvl0 \i {\listtext \f1\i0 \uc0\u9642 \f0\i }Hard to tell differences between results. \i0 Google results don\'92t show software features\'97you must investigate each result & compare them yourself.}
